Award.AwardTitle: Examining the role of nanoparticles in the formation and degradation of methylated mercury in the ocean
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Environmental Chemistry Program in the Chemistry Division at the National Science Foundation, Professors Robert Mason and Jing Zhao of the University of Connecticut examine the role of nanoparticles in controlling the reactions between various forms of mercury in the ocean. Specifically, in contrast to freshwater environments, dimethylmercury is found in all ocean waters where measurements have been made. There is little information on its formation mechanisms. The investigators have preliminary evidence to indicate that it may be formed by reactions that involve nanoparticles and other surfaces. It is known that methylmercury, an organic form of mercury found in the ocean, is mostly formed by bacteria that react with inorganic mercury. Reactive surfaces are also be important in the degradation of methylmercury. The project trains a graduate student in diverse aspects of environment chemistry, and engages undergraduates and high school students, providing avenues for research, teaching and outreach. The investigators incorporate the research into ongoing outreach programs. They use the information generated from the project in developing their graduate and undergraduate teaching curricula. The results are published in the peer-reviewed literature, with the graduate student as the lead author.

The investigators conduct laboratory experiments with both commercially manufactured and natural nanomaterials to examine the potential importance of metal nanoparticles in forming metallic and organic forms of mercury under conditions applicable to the ocean. Techniques used in these experiments include UV-visible and fluorescence spectroscopy, electron microscopy and mass spectrometry. Mercury analyses require instruments that are specifically designed for measurement of the different forms of mercury at low concentrations. The results of this research enhance our understanding of the processes that form methylated mercury in the ocean which, when bioaccumulated into seafood is an important human health concern. Professors Mason and Zhao incorporate their findings into their outreach communications with managers and regulators interested in mitigating the impacts of anthropogenic mercury emissions on the biosphere through such treaties as the Minamata Convention.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project "Examining the role of nanoparticles in the formation and degradation of methylated mercury in the ocean" examined the interaction of mercury (Hg) with manufactured nanoparticles (NPs), principally those termed ?quantum dots? as these NPs are typically composed of elements with which Hg is known to react. The NPs which were the focus of the study were composed of metals (Hg and cadmium (Cd)) and either sulfur (S) or selenium (Se) with the form MeX where Me represents the metal and X is the S or Se; e.g. CdSe. The study was designed to provide insight into what could happen when these NPs are released into the environment in waste treatment waters or from other sources. Also, there is the potential for similar types of NPs to be formed in the environment in regions of low oxygen and therefore the studies were also pertinent to these naturally-formed NPs. One recurring question in environmental science is the synergistic impact of multiple contaminants in the water as they can combine to form more toxic end products. Here we were examining the NPs, which are relatively toxic in their own right, but also how their interactions with Hg would change their toxicity and environmental impact.

Intellectual Merit: The studies that were completed advanced understanding of the complexity of chemical interactions in environmental media and demonstrated how the release of a chemical into the environment, including NPs and other particulate materials, can lead to multiple and unexpected interactions. The NPs that were used fluoresce, and in the presence of inorganic Hg (Hg(II)) or methylmercury (CH3Hg, referred to as MeHg) the fluorescence is decreased. Examining the change in fluorescence at different concentrations and in different media allowed for an examination of the interactions and the mechanism of the fluorescence quenching. For MeHg, the NPs also resulted in its transformation. While our studies with MeX micro-particles (CdS or iron sulfide (FeS)) had shown the conversion of MeHg into the more toxic dimethylmercury ((CH3)2Hg or DMeHg), this was not the case with the NPs and we concluded that the difference was because in the formation of these NPs they are coated with an organic compound to keep the size small and enhance their stability. The presence of the coating reduced the reaction but we did show that in the presence of light that the organic coating can be degraded and as a result the reaction increased dramatically, but in this case the MeHg was degraded to Hg(II), which precipitated onto the surface of the NP. This is shown schematically in the attached figure. There is the potential that the Hg could exchange with the Cd within CdSe NPs, but this was not found to occur. Similarly, while it was shown that Hg(II) could be converted to elemental Hg (Hg(0)) in the presence of FeS micro-particles, there was not such formation in the presence of CdSe NPs.

Broader Impacts: The results of these studies demonstrated the potential environmental impact of the release of manufactured NPs into the environment and caution against this occurring. The chemistry of these interactions, which is consistent with the manufactured design, can have large impacts within aquatic ecosystems that can be beneficial or lead to enhanced toxicity. More studies are needed to further examine these potential interactions and their consequences. The studies were completed by two PhD students and a post-doc, with other students helping with specific analytical measurements. The students were trained and gained their PhD degrees. The post-doc gained experience that will enhance her ability to succeed in an academic research environment. The results of the study were published in the scientific literature and included in the classes taught by the PIs at the University of Connecticut.
